segments.text: an interview with General H.O.
Johnson, Jr., Brigadier General, United States Air Force, retired.
Today's date is July 15, 1981.
This is Terry Anderson.
This is our second interview with General Johnson, Brigadier General, United States Air Force, retired.
Today is July 15th, 1981.
This is Terry Anderson.
And last time we were talking about your job in Great Britain as the Director of Project Management of the Third Air Force.
And you had written down a couple of things there that you wanted to talk about that you said were rather interesting about that job.
And then a tape ran out.
Okay.
I think we had talked about Project Red Richard and the move of certainly the nuclear force from France over to England.
At the time that I was forecasted to leave England and return to the United States,
an alert came through that I was going to be reassigned to the ROTC program.
And when I approached my supervisor, who was then Colonel Frank Collins, he suggested that if I knew anybody in the higher
echelons of the personnel business that I contact them, and he would contact the top civil engineer who was Major General Minton and see if we couldn't do something about that.
Well, sure enough, the three-star general who was in charge of personnel at the time was named Clark, and he happened to be the wing commander at Chaumont, where I had
some three or four years earlier, served as his resident engineer.
And it seemed that, yes, the assignment to ROTC was stopped, and Clark and Minton made the decision for me to come to the Pentagon.
I was then in a dilemma because I didn't know which would be the
lesser of two evils to go back to ROTC or to go to the Pentagon because it was my desire to try to stay as close to engineering as I could for another few years.
I didn't have any idea what I might get into in the Pentagon.
So it happened that I was assigned as chief of the master planning branch of
civil engineering at headquarters US Air Force.
It was a very enlightening assignment that I held for three years.
From 1960 to 1963, but before we get to that job, sir, I'd like to ask you one question about Red Richard and about storing nuclear weapons in the United Kingdom.
Our first Polaris submarines were reaching England by 1960 and there was a little bit of anti-nuclear weapon protests from some factions in the British
Maybe later on, and I was wondering if any of this, if you had any anti-neutro demonstrations, do you remember any of this or your feelings on that?

Well, I remember it vividly because it's strange that you would bring it up without any prompting at all, but I was given a special assignment for a week or ten days to accompany two Navy commanders as we surveyed
bases in Scotland and Ireland that had been made available to us by the British.
And since the Air Force was the point of contact with the British, it was our job to put somebody with them.
And the three of us went to some 10 or 12 bases that the British had made available to us to store the nuclear weapons for the Polaris.
The three of us were the ones that actually made the decision to put them in Scotland.
And there they still are, for that matter.
Now, as far as the people that were anti were the minority, most of the people in Scotland,
kind of looked upon it as a blessing in disguise because it was more employment that other people would have.
We ended up in a later assignment
I don't know what the dates, you got the dates, when I went back there in 68.
And built a number of houses.
We built some 200 houses in Scotland just to support that force.
Those houses were actually not US owned, but British owned and leased to us.
So when I say British, Scottish is probably a better term to use than Scotland.
We didn't really feel any hard feelings from the people.
Was this done spectacularized by the media, that some of these protests?
Oh, it always is, sure.
Okay, I was wondering about that.
Okay, now let's move to Washington, D.C., and tell me about life in the Pentagon.
Well, life in the Pentagon is...
It's a peculiar life.
If there's anything that's different from the military, it's probably life in the Pentagon, because you work at different hours.
You work strange hours, erratic hours, unless you are
fortunate enough to be of a real high rank, and therefore given one of the few sets of quarters that are available to support the Pentagon.
You live on the economy.
And you make your own private and social life.
And very, very little of it is associated with the military.
You are nothing more than just another person living in the Washington area.
you may or may not live in a neighborhood where there are other military people.
Certainly there's going to be other people working for the federal government, because I guess 60, 70% of them in that area do work for the federal government.
But other than the fact that you are in either the headquarters of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, or Department of Defense,
Most of the time you even wear civilian clothes, and it doesn't take long to begin to feel that we're in the world that the military go.
I found the three years to be a very enlightening three years, both politically, professionally,
travel-wide and everything else because of some of the work that we did during the three-year period.
The one that drew me in closest association with the other services was the
Army, Navy, and Air Force and Marines had different agencies and organizations scattered all over the District of Columbia.
They also had, at that time, quarters for enlisted personnel of the unmarried type scattered all over the area.
And the Department of Defense took it upon themselves

start a project of consolidating to try to cut back on the amount of space required which would also generate a dollar savings and one of us from each of the four services was placed on the committee and we worked for some six or eight months on the project constantly briefing

the local congressmen, that is those from Virginia and Maryland, how it would affect them as well as briefing the House Armed Service Committee what we were doing to the defense establishment in the District of Columbia.
And it did result in a considerable consolidation and a little more
effective planning for the future because all four services were going their own way rather than cooperating with each other and sharing space or making surplus space available to the other service.
And so did you actually establish?
Yes.
What was the name of that?
Well, it was known as the Washington Consolidation Plan.
And part of that plan actually closed
Naval Air Station Anacostia and placed that Navy personnel was there in the facilities over on Boeing, which gave up part of the Anacostia base.
The only thing that stayed on Anacostia was a Marine detachment that was charged with the emergency evacuation of the President and his family out of the White House.
That installation where their helicopter stayed
But everything else in Anacostia moved off and was consolidated to other locations.
And what was the end result?
Well, the end result, of course, was a dollar saving and a more effective future planning by just cutting back one installation in Anacostia and the D.C. area.
Because that land had been turned back to other public use, taken out of the defense inventory.
Was also the result of a new agency that was a centralized planning agency?
No, it was not.
Why not?
Well, there's no reason to establish an agency that the Department of Defense is already responsible for.
Okay, so it's all... Now, is this...
At the same time, of course, there were other consolidations going on in the military.
For example, the rise of the Defense Intelligence Agency, in which they took the Defense Intelligence Agency from all three services and put them into one in Washington.
Does this seem like it's part of a pattern, then, to consolidate and streamline the military during the early 1960s?
Well, yes, it was.
Of course, when the DIA was formed,
They didn't require new quarters.
They went into existing army quarters that were over in Maryland.
Now the task that was assigned to the master planning branch that I found the most interesting as far as just the Air Force was concerned and what constantly had me before committees of Congress was
a program known as the Access Road Program.
Each year, the different services request from the Congress an appropriation to support roads that are contiguous to their installations that are used

not only by the their people on the installations but by the public such as roads that would lead to randolph air force base or roads that would lead to bergstrom and what improvements need to be made to those roads to carry the traffic actually the cost is born by the the service concern the big

thing at that time of course is we were now installing the Minuteman missiles and this required miles and miles and miles of road improvements to carry the transporter erector of the Minuteman from the storage depot to the silo or the location that the Minuteman would be placed in which the Minuteman would be placed.

Malmstrom Air Force Base was our first installation and we improved thousands of miles of road in Montana and all these roads had to be traveled with Bureau of Public Road People and state people determined whether or not the road was sufficient to carry
Well, the first thing we had to do was... You had to turn weight?
I beg your pardon?
Because of the vehicle's weight?
Not only weight, but also such thing as the turning rate of it.

So the first thing we had to do was to go out to the plant where they were making the transporter erector and fully load one and put it through its paces and measure everything to see what it took to turn it and to back it up and so on, on public roads.
Once it got on the installation,
handle that, or into the small square, which was Air Force property.
But on the public roads, we had to increase the radius on many, many square turn out there, where in that part of the country, most of the roads follow league lines.
And they're pretty square as compared to our part of the country, where roads run diagonal curve down in this part of Texas.
This Access Road Program became so much more visible during this period that
with or without my consent, and at that time they didn't ask people in my grade if they incurred in certain things, they just said this is the way it's going to be done.

When I moved from that position to Chief of the Master Planning Branch to the next one that I had, which was in the office of the Secretary of the Air Force, they also transferred the responsibility of the coordination of access roads from
the master planning branch to the office that I transferred to.
And I kept that same thing the whole time that I was there.
Was that because of the quality of job you were doing?
I don't know.
One would like to think so.
But I became known as Access Road Johnson.
The staff knew me as such.
If I went in to put on a briefing, will everybody immediately assume that it was on access roads?
It may not necessarily have been, but I had the full knowledge of the access roads and the ear of a couple of the congressmen who followed it constantly because of the dollars that we were spending.
Who were these congressmen?
Harry Shepard from California was probably the leading one.
chairman of the subcommittee of House Appropriations.
That's where we, of course, derive our money in.
But each, as you can imagine, Montana is not a very big state.
And I don't even know how many congressmen they have.
But every time we go into an area, naturally, if we're going to do anything to public roads in a congressional district,
The congressman wanted to know about it and would have preferred to even make the announcement.
Sometimes that was a little difficult because we were moving faster than that.
But most of the time, we could cooperate with him and say, OK, here's what we're going to do.
We're going to improve the roads from here to here.
So they wanted the publicity.
Sure.
They may or may not have had anything to do with it, but any time a congressman can tell his home constituents something,
he gets some credit, whether he deserves it or not.
So it was back and forth from what we call the Pentagon to up on the hill, and constantly keeping them.
And many, many trips to the field, again,
there were public road people and state road people and so on because we couldn't touch the road.
We could not let the contract on the road because they're a public road.
We provide the money and we provide the criteria.
This is what it's got to be raised to in order that we can move it across.
Did you have any problems or was this carried out?
The biggest problem that I had in it, I was then in the secretary's office and I was working for
A Deputy Assistant Secretary for Air Force installation named Alan McCone, a gentleman from Pennsylvania, happens to be deceased, but now.
But the cost of the improvements of the access roads in Missouri got to be such a, estimated to be at such a terrific level that

was going to cost four to five times what we had originally estimated and our estimates had been based on what it had cost in other locations but missouri doesn't have the same type of road base and soils and everything else that malmstrom has for instance and we had carried our problem to the
powers to be in the Air Force, and a decision was made that we would probably relocate the Minuteman wing to another area.
And it fell my boss's job, Alan McCone, to go tell Senator Symington that the Minuteman was not going to be located in Missouri.
This is the same as signing your own death warrant, because Symington was not only a leader
of the Senate, but he was also a former Secretary of the Air Force.
And Mr. McCone chose not to go alone, but Colonel Johnson was going to go with him and explain why.
Can you tell me about that?
Well, it was interesting.
And what year was this?
This is 19...
into the Secretary's office.
This would be between 1963 and 68.
Well, it would be immediately before Kennedy's assassination because with the assassination, McCone tendered his resignation.
He was a political appointee.
So it would be about October of 1963.
This was of the party and looked like there would be peace and harmony in the party, but that's not always so.
Simon can sit and listen.
He listened to McCone make the preamble.
He listened to part of my briefing is to back up the preamble as to what was driving the cost up and so on.
And without saying a word to us, picked up this phone and said, get me Gene.
Gene is Gene Zucker, the Secretary of the Air Force.
The next thing he says, Gene, you've got a little fat man over here with a colonel and, hey, what did you say your name was?
And pointed to McCone and said, Alan McCone.
Alan McCone.
He tells me you can't put the minute man in Missouri.
I want you to call me back and tell me how we're going to solve this problem.
It's a good day, gentlemen.
And that was the start of how we spent some time relocating sites in Missouri to pull the costs down, going back for more money.
Anyway, the Minuteman Wing is located in Missouri.
Even at a higher cost to the taxpayer?
Yes.
And where did you think was the optimal site?
At that time, we weren't looking at other sites.
In other words, I wasn't in the area of trying to determine where else, because there are too many things involved.
Targeting, support bays.
support bases, maybe.
We weren't looking at other sites.
The problem right then and there was to let Sidington know that it was too costly.
And you may even look back and say, OK, it was effective because he helped get additional money.
Yeah.
It could have been done a lot cheaper someplace else.
The term lot, I don't know, but it's definitely cheaper as far as road improvements.
And the cost of the roads was such that we couldn't move it alone.
I mean, it took more than just our decision that it was going to be moved.
But when the Air Force had to put it on the scale and say, gosh, it could cost that much more, we've got to find another place, another location.
But that was a...
A real interesting month, six week period of...
Were there other problems with the project?
No, not necessarily.
We have... Well yes, we had one other and that was with Senator Fulbright in Arkansas.

managed to get through an amendment to the Public Road Act, a provision whereby, and they didn't necessarily spell out airport, but when any of the Department of Defense forces or elements or some term damaged
public roads, that the public roads would in turn be restored and paid for by funds from the Department of Defense.
And this caused no end of concern because we felt that this was an open book to, gee, there goes an army truck.
Let's stick them for the repair of this road.
Well, hell, the road may have needed repaired for the last four or five years, sure.
We didn't have any success of stopping the thing.
The amendment did pass.
But by the execution of it through the Bureau of Public Road, we were able to minimize
costs that were thrown back to the different departments by close surveillance of the condition of all roads in which we used on a routine basis.
We know whether or not, or have an idea as to whether, yes, we were responsible for the damage.
Bridge structures are easy to determine because
by the Bureau constantly inspecting the bridges.
And then if we put heavy loads across for an extended period of time, well, you could pretty well determine that you're the guy.
But the hearings with Senator Fulbright were not the most social that I've ever been through.
It was a very difficult .
In what way?

uh pretty much like my father he's setting his ways and he's going to have his way and he's going to play the game his way or he's going to take his football and go home of course he was on his ground which is up on the hill and we're up there away from the pentagon and

Senate and Congressional hearings are, if the public could ever see some of them, they would absolutely be disgusted with the type of people that they send to Washington because you can effect when the media says at the Senate hearing today on so-and-so that
Everybody was there, and it was run right.
And sure enough, there'll be one senator sitting across the table from maybe six or eight witnesses from the Department of the Air Force.
And this one senator, he's conducting the hearing.
And that's written as if the entire committee was there, and everything was going on.
And it's...
It's far from the democratic way of doing things, I think, but that's the way it is.
Well, now that we're on this topic, I wanted to have your opinion of congressmen as a general group.

I mean, when you were out in Washington dealing with congressmen, did your opinion of the Congress and the way our democracy works, those politicians, did it increase or did it decrease or change in any way?
Well, no, because
You realize that from what we've already said, I grew up in a political atmosphere.
My dad worked for the city and then making races for the railroad commissioner.
I had known congressmen and known senators and known people that worked for government.
I wouldn't say that it had any effect on it.
I will say that
I'm trying to think of this congressman's name.
He was from the Tidewater area of Virginia.
When we had this Washington consolidation plan, we had a breakfast meeting one morning in which we briefed the committee he was on.
And he became the culprit of the committee that was going to really
really put us all on the spot, and right in the middle of it.
And he could get away with something like this because we were now on neutral ground.
We weren't on the hill.
We weren't in the Pentagon.
We were in a place having breakfast, and blood and breathings were going on.
And right in the middle of all of his dogmatic questioning, he says, wouldn't you like to be on my side asking the questions instead of on your side having to answer?
Showing that the man did have a sense of humor.
He knew that he was a browbeatenist, but no, I can't say that it's even now.
Would you say you have a high or a low opinion of the Congress?
Neither.
I don't have a high opinion of them.

Maybe that's influenced a little bit by political feelings, and I'm sure it is, because I think that two of the congressmen that we have from this general location ought to be replaced, and I'm tickled to death with one of them, and that's the political party.
Okay, so much for Congress.
Tiger Teague was a personal friend, and I thought he was pretty good at that.
So much for Congress.
Were there other programs besides the Access Road Program that you thought was very important in the early 1960s that you were working on?
Well,
I haven't moved from the master planning branch in the end to the secretary's office.
And then, of course, that was in the secretary's office when we went over to see Simon.
Then following Kennedy's assassination, well, Allie McComb resigned or tendered his resignation.
It was accepted, and he was replaced by a gentleman by the name of Lou Turner, who also is deceased at this time.
Shortly after Turner came aboard, McNamara
formed or started the base closure, the retrenchment.
And two of us from Turner's staff were assigned to the committee to study out and help determine which

air force bases were vulnerable or which should be considered for closure or for reduction or whatever this this proved to be very interesting and as a satellite i might say the second person was a individual by the name of joe meese and uh
Joe Meese now happens to have the job that Mr. Turner had.
He is the Deputy Assistant Secretary for the Air Force Bar Installations.
He has risen on the ranks.
It was interesting to go through and study and make the recommendations and have them reviewed by both what we call the air staff, that's the ones that are under the

chief of staff the four-star general and then pass to the secretary for his review and then on to pick him up the department of defense here's the product from the air force and so on and then sit at department of defense and see what's coming in from the other
the Army, the Navy, and the Marines.
And what did you think were some of the bases that could have been closed?
Do you remember some of those bases?
You probably traveled around.
We traveled, yeah.
And did a lot of evaluation.
Do you remember what those bases were?
Oh, I can go back and look in the files that I have, but just to start calling them, because we closed a number of bases.
The one that we kept trying to close but they wouldn't let us close was Ellington.
Of course, the reason they wouldn't let us close is it was in direct support of NASA, but it was straight Air Force funding that was keeping Ellington open and keeping
a colonel and a staff down there, and when you've got military people, you end up with a PX and the commissary, and sure, so you've got the base open.

And so having the base, then you start looking for some type of troops, and we ended up putting reserve forces in there that flew on the weekends, things like the National Guard unit, and then you've got the base flourishing again.
But sure, we said close it, but we could never close it.
But one of the most interesting things that took place was
in this exercise was there was a leak in one of the other services.
I don't recall whether it was Army or Navy, but it was one of the two.
And this was, of course, the last thing that McNamara wanted was that there be absolutely tight security until public announcement was made
After that, it was a fait accompli.
No turn back.
This is what's going to happen.
The decision has been made, and pop.
Anytime there's a leak, you always throw yourself wide open to second thoughts, power groups coming in, do this, do that, and so on.
So our boss, Mr. Turner, was a man that had spent many, many years in the Air Force,

In fact, it had started as a GS-1 or 2 and had come up through the ranks and left the Air Force probably as a GS-15 and went into public to private practice working for a contractor out in California and had spent three years out there.
When McCone resigned, well, Zucker called Turner and back and asked him if he would like to have this particular job.
He knew a lot about the Air Force.
He knew a lot about the Department of Defense, unlike most political appointees that come in and then spend their first six months behind the learning curve.
But we went to the boss and told him of the leak.
and told him of the pressure that was being put on us.
And he hit upon a very clever idea in which we called General Cappucci over to the office to discuss it with him.
Now, General Cappucci was the head, at that time, was the head of
The Air Force OSI, which is the Office of Special Investigation, they're the ones that run all of our background clearances.
They are the secret police, whatever you want to call them, in the Air Force.
I think in the Army it's called the Army Security Agency, ASA or something.
They have their own codes.
Their agents are the only ones that can decode a message.
And you will find a detachment of the OSI on every Air Force base or major installation, the difference being base has a runway, installation does not have a runway.
For instance, my son is the detachment commander right now of the OSI at a base in England, and there are three agents on that base.
He's the top.
But they maintain their own code.
And we proposed to Cappucci that the Air Force instructions would go out through his channel and not through the normal communication channels.
Now you can, right quick, anybody in mathematics can figure out how many people that's knocked out of knowledge of what's in that coded message.
First, code in Washington.
How many people would have known what was in the message?
And then when the message got to the base, how many people would see the message, either before it's coded, after it was decoded, and then pass to the commander
through his secretary or through his adjutant who would then have knowledge.
Whereas the agents working in the OSI would receive the coded message, decode it, and he himself walked to the base commander and say, sir, this message has come for you through my channel.
If that were broken, then we're in trouble.
So we used that system and needless to say, there was no security.
There were other security leaks later on in two of the services, but none in the airport.
But again, this took an awful lot of close work with Capucci and his people.
And the main thing was that the Air Force wanted to be sure that when

trying to reach for a base, just by memory, that when McNamara announced that Air Force Base X would close and the media hit the commander of Base X ten minutes later and the colonel sits there and says, I don't know anything about it, he was knowledgeable.
He knew it was going to close.

we don't like to put our people in the spotlight right and uh so they were just as knowledgeable as it could be but under certain limitations so you thought that the way that this was handled by mcnamara was effectively very definitely uh like i said a while ago if you and i know uh this
the history that you're reporting, is that oftentimes leaks are deliberate.
Yeah.
But a leak in this instance is the worst thing that could have happened.
Because like I said, if pressure droops the chance to come back and appeal, take a second look, if the Secretary of Defense is knowledgeable and

capable as McNamara would his staff, different staff or services all got together and made the decision within the ground rules, we've got the attitude and the climate and the money we've got got to cut back.
These are the ones that are going outside help can only hinder to the decision making process.
Later on the
Years later, when I was in Department of Defense, the Army made a decision to close a certain base.
It was announced, and it was put on what's called the reserve list.
That meant that the base had to sit there and couldn't be utilized for anything by permanent change of the facility.
Well, the people of that area came to Department of Defense and said, look.
And it was strange, because that particular assistant secretary had me in the office with him.
And he said, I want you to speak to this whenever you can.
And on one side of the room, the contingent from Mineral Wells, right here in Texas, the one I mentioned the other day,
We had it for the Aviation and Air Force.
When the Army took it, they made a helicopter school out of it.
And of course, the Army closed that school and moved everything to Alabama and put it in one school where they were operating two.
And half of this continued for mental well.
These people over on this side of the room said, please don't close it.
We can prove that we can train helicopter pilots cheaper than they can train them over in Alabama.
People over on this side of the room said, but sir, if you close it, don't put it on the reserve list.
Leave it to us so that we can bring industry in and use the facilities to help the community.
So here, this contingent for mineral wells was split.
But don't close it.
If you do close it, take it off the list.
And of course, all the secretary can do is say, sir, it's closed.
I'll try to help you.
Sure.
You get the feeling for these people, but you've got to remember first that we're still in the defense business.
I was wondering about your thoughts about the very controversial Secretary of Defense, Matthew Brown.
You had a lot of dealings with him.
Well, I can tell you a story that
Maybe we'll put in a very few words.
The Assistant Secretary that
that my boss worked for of the Air Force.
Having a meeting in his office one day, I'll read you in a minute.
And he was sitting at the head of the table, and immediately to his left was my boss, Mr. Turner.
And then the table was surrounded by other high-ranking officers and civilians.
I was sitting across the table from Mr. Turner, and therefore I was on
On the Secretary's right hand.
On McNamara's?
No.
This was the Assistant Secretary of the Air Force.
And McNamara and Johnson had just pulled something that even their own administration and Department of Defense and the Air Force were just absolutely disgusting.
They just went against the grain.
President Johnson.
President Johnson.
And this assistant secretary had sounded off, even though he was of the party and of that administration.
He sounded off and spoke bitterly against it and then turned to Mr. Turner and said, Lou, what do you think about that?
Do you remember what the issue was?
No, I don't.
And Lou sounded off.
And then it proceeded to go all the way around the table.
And the guy on my right said something.
I didn't say anything.
The secretary turned to me and he said, Huh?
Just because you're the lowest rank at the table, that doesn't mean you have...
